BaseAudioContext.summary: The BaseAudioContext interface of the Web Audio API acts as a base definition for online and offline audio-processing graphs, as represented by and respectively. You wouldn't use BaseAudioContext directly — you'd use its features via one of these two inheriting interfaces.

remarks.para: A BaseAudioContext can be a target of events, therefore it implements the interface.

BaseAudioContextAudioWorklet.summary:
The audioWorklet read-only property of the
interface returns an instance of
that can be used for adding
-derived classes which implement custom audio
processing.

BaseAudioContextCreateAnalyser.summary:
The createAnalyser() method of the
interface creates an , which
can be used to expose audio time and frequency data and create data visualizations.

blockquote.para:
The constructor is the
recommended way to create an ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

For more on using this node, see the
page.

BaseAudioContextCreateBiquadFilter.summary:
The createBiquadFilter() method of the
interface creates a , which represents a second order
filter configurable as several different common filter types.

blockquote.para:
The constructor is the
recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateBuffer.summary:
The createBuffer() method of the
Interface is used to create a new, empty object, which
can then be populated by data, and played via an .

remarks.para:
For more details about audio buffers, check out the
reference page.

blockquote.para:
createBuffer() used to be able to take compressed
data and give back decoded samples, but this ability was removed from the specification,
because all the decoding was done on the main thread, so
createBuffer() was blocking other code execution. The asynchronous method
decodeAudioData() does the same thing — takes compressed audio, such as an
MP3 file, and directly gives you back an that you can
then play via an . For simple use cases
like playing an MP3, decodeAudioData() is what you should be using.

remarks.para: For an in-depth explanation of how audio buffers work, including what the parameters do, read Audio buffers: frames, samples and channels from our Basic concepts guide.

BaseAudioContextCreateBuffer.returns: An configured based on the specified options.

BaseAudioContextCreateBufferSource.summary:
The createBufferSource() method of the
Interface is used to create a new , which can be
used to play audio data contained within an object.
s are created using or returned by when it successfully decodes an audio track.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create an ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateChannelMerger.summary:
The createChannelMerger() method of the interface creates a ,
which combines channels from multiple audio streams into a single audio stream.

blockquote.para:
The constructor is the
recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateChannelSplitter.summary:
The createChannelSplitter() method of the Interface is used to create a ,
which is used to access the individual channels of an audio stream and process them separately.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateConstantSource.summary:
The createConstantSource()
property of the interface creates a
object, which is an audio source that continuously
outputs a monaural (one-channel) sound signal whose samples all have the same
value.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateConvolver.summary:
The createConvolver() method of the
interface creates a , which is commonly used to apply
reverb effects to your audio. See the spec definition of Convolution for more information.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateDelay.summary:
The createDelay() method of the
Interface is used to create a ,
which is used to delay the incoming audio signal by a certain amount of time.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateDynamicsCompressor.summary: The createDynamicsCompressor() method of the Interface is used to create a , which can be used to apply compression to an audio signal.

remarks.para:
Compression lowers the volume of the loudest parts of the signal and raises the volume
of the softest parts. Overall, a louder, richer, and fuller sound can be achieved. It is
especially important in games and musical applications where large numbers of individual
sounds are played simultaneously, where you want to control the overall signal level and
help avoid clipping (distorting) of the audio output.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateGain.summary:
The createGain() method of the
interface creates a , which can be used to control the
overall gain (or volume) of the audio graph.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateGain.returns:
A which takes as input one or more audio sources and outputs
audio whose volume has been adjusted in gain (volume) to a level specified by the node's
a-rate
parameter.

BaseAudioContextCreateIIRFilter.summary: The createIIRFilter() method of the interface creates an , which represents a general infinite impulse response (IIR) filter which can be configured to serve as various types of filter.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create an ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateIIRFilter.returns:
An implementing the filter with the specified feedback and
feedforward coefficient arrays.

BaseAudioContextCreateOscillator.summary:
The createOscillator() method of the
interface creates an , a source representing a periodic
waveform. It basically generates a constant tone.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create an ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreatePanner.summary:
The createPanner() method of the
Interface is used to create a new , which is used to
spatialize an incoming audio stream in 3D space.

remarks.para:
The panner node is spatialized in relation to the AudioContext's
(defined by the
attribute), which represents the position and orientation of the person listening to the
audio.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreatePeriodicWave.summary: The createPeriodicWave() method of the interface is used to create a . This wave is used to define a periodic waveform that can be used to shape the output of an .

BaseAudioContextCreateScriptProcessor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The createScriptProcessor() method of the interface
creates a used for direct audio processing.

blockquote.para: This feature was replaced by AudioWorklets and the interface.

BaseAudioContextCreateStereoPanner.summary:
The createStereoPanner() method of the interface creates a , which can be used to apply
stereo panning to an audio source.
It positions an incoming audio stream in a stereo image using a low-cost panning algorithm.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCreateWaveShaper.summary:
The createWaveShaper() method of the
interface creates a , which represents a non-linear
distortion. It is used to apply distortion effects to your audio.

blockquote.para:
The
constructor is the recommended way to create a ; see
Creating an AudioNode.

BaseAudioContextCurrentTime.summary:
The currentTime read-only property of the
interface returns a double representing an ever-increasing hardware timestamp in seconds that
can be used for scheduling audio playback, visualizing timelines, etc. It starts at 0.

BaseAudioContextDecodeAudioData.summary:
The decodeAudioData() method of the
Interface is used to asynchronously decode audio file data contained in an
{{jsxref("ArrayBuffer")}} that is loaded from ,
, or . The decoded
is resampled to the 's sampling
rate, then passed to a callback or promise.

remarks.para:
This is the preferred method of creating an audio source for Web Audio API from an
audio track. This method only works on complete file data, not fragments of audio file
data.

This function implements two alternative ways to asynchronously return the audio data or error messages: it returns a that fulfills with the audio data, and also accepts callback arguments to handle success or failure. The primary method of interfacing with this function is via its Promise return value, and the callback parameters are provided for legacy reasons.

BaseAudioContextDecodeAudioData.returns:
A object that fulfills with the decodedData. If you are using the
XHR syntax you will ignore this return value and use a callback function instead.

BaseAudioContextDestination.summary:
The destination property of the
interface returns an representing the final
destination of all audio in the context. It often represents an actual audio-rendering
device such as your device's speakers.

BaseAudioContextListener.summary:
The listener property of the interface
returns an object that can then be used for
implementing 3D audio spatialization.

BaseAudioContextSampleRate.summary:
The sampleRate property of the interface returns a floating point number representing the sample rate, in samples per second, used by all nodes in this audio context.
This limitation means that sample-rate converters are not supported.
BaseAudioContextSampleRate.value:
A floating point number indicating the audio context's sample rate, in samples per
second.

BaseAudioContextState.summary:
The state read-only property of the
interface returns the current state of the AudioContext.

BaseAudioContextStatechange.summary: A statechange event is fired at a object when its member changes.
